page.title: 10BOWNESS-ON-SOLWAY.BUILDINGS.
page.content: Bowness stands literally on its Roman foundations (see:HISTORY TO 1603). Its main street (E-W) is closely aligned on that of the fort. Much pillaged stone has been used and re-used. The village has mostly small scale dwellings and narrow streets. Pevsner gives the Church as late Norman with restorations of 1891. The Rectory is of Gothic style, but built in 1922. Most houses & cottages are in local red sandstone, cobble or brick, some rendered, all with slate roofs. Dating varies from 17C. to 19C. Sub P.O., school extensions & some bungalows & houses on village edges are 20C. Bowness House Farm (village centre) incorporates a listed building, probably oldest extant, in red sandstone with ornate doorcase. Interior date reads 1694.
